update.description:
* Use `rendering::JointVisual` to preview joints inside model editor

* Changing a joint's data on the joint inspector updates the visual with the new `JointVisual::UpdateFromMsg` function

* Added tests for the `JointVisual::UpdateFromMsg` function



![joint5.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4087862374-joint5.png)
update.title: Model Editor: Joint visuals

content.html: Ticketed issue #1410

content.raw: I think we may not need the `GetPartWorldCentroid` function any more as it doesn't make much sense now. So the change looks good
content.html: I think we may not need the GetPartWorldCentroid function any more as it doesn't make much sense now. So the change looks good

content.raw: I can't speak to the subtleties of when to calculate the centroid, but the fix works!
content.html: I can't speak to the subtleties of when to calculate the centroid, but the fix works!

content.raw:
This was happening because, for some reason, the world pose of the link's children wasn't getting updated fast enough, messing with `GetPartWorldCentroid`.

So on commit 759e8bd, I anchor the hotspot visual to the link's pose rather than the centroid of its visuals. Ultimately, I think this is a good idea because the joint pose is expressed w.r.t. the child link's pose, not the centroid, so the hotspot becomes more informative.

I left the centroid calculation on mouse move during joint creation, not sure about it though.

Anyways, I think that for the current version of the model editor, the link's pose always equals the centroid, because each link has only one visual and one collision visual, both with zero local pose. However, with the part inspector, the user will be able to add more visuals and edit their local poses, thus affecting the centroid. What do you think about all this, @iche033?
content.html:
This was happening because, for some reason, the world pose of the link's children wasn't getting updated fast enough, messing with GetPartWorldCentroid.

So on commit 759e8bd, I anchor the hotspot visual to the link's pose rather than the centroid of its visuals. Ultimately, I think this is a good idea because the joint pose is expressed w.r.t. the child link's pose, not the centroid, so the hotspot becomes more informative.

I left the centroid calculation on mouse move during joint creation, not sure about it though.

Anyways, I think that for the current version of the model editor, the link's pose always equals the centroid, because each link has only one visual and one collision visual, both with zero local pose. However, with the part inspector, the user will be able to add more visuals and edit their local poses, thus affecting the centroid. What do you think about all this, @iche033?

content.raw:
1. Make two shapes
2. Connect with a joint
3. Snap the shapes together

![snaptool.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3156360804-snaptool.png)
content.html:
1. Make two shapes
  2. Connect with a joint
  3. Snap the shapes together

content.raw: Right, I wonder if there's a way of unchecking the special Gazebo markers (collisions, joints, CoM etc.) with one event that fires upon entering the model editor. You would probably want to save the settings before entering the model editor and then re-check the saved settings once the model editor is exited. Sounds like it's probably meant for a different PR though.
content.html: Right, I wonder if there's a way of unchecking the special Gazebo markers (collisions, joints, CoM etc.) with one event that fires upon entering the model editor. You would probably want to save the settings before entering the model editor and then re-check the saved settings once the model editor is exited. Sounds like it's probably meant for a different PR though.

content.raw: This bothers me too. A quick solution would be to trigger `g_showJointsAct` once if it is checked and twice if it is unchecked. This takes a lot of lines of code though... Especially if you do the same for transparency, wireframe, collisions, CoM and so on. I'm looking into a way of directly calling [Scene::ShowJoints](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/66de1887edea28bec5d8b94de5e74f035ac53cc0/gazebo/rendering/Scene.cc?at=default#cl-2866) when the editor is opened.
content.html: This bothers me too. A quick solution would be to trigger g_showJointsAct once if it is checked and twice if it is unchecked. This takes a lot of lines of code though... Especially if you do the same for transparency, wireframe, collisions, CoM and so on. I'm looking into a way of directly calling Scene::ShowJoints when the editor is opened.

content.raw: Fixed issues on another branch (commit 6db3c36), let me know if you're ok with them and I'll merge it in.
content.html: Fixed issues on another branch (commit 6db3c36), let me know if you're ok with them and I'll merge it in.

content.raw: I'm having some issues on your branch, for example, changing joint type on the inspector behaves weirdly sometimes, and scaling the child link changes the position of the joint. I'll see if I can fix them.
content.html: I'm having some issues on your branch, for example, changing joint type on the inspector behaves weirdly sometimes, and scaling the child link changes the position of the joint. I'll see if I can fix them.

content.raw:
Small UI thing, not sure if we care about it or not:

Build a model with a joint

Save and leave the model editor

Right click on the model, "View Joints"

the joint appears in the right place

Re-open the model editor, the JointVisual for the finished model is still visible.
content.html:
Small UI thing, not sure if we care about it or not:

Build a model with a joint

Save and leave the model editor

Right click on the model, "View Joints"

the joint appears in the right place

Re-open the model editor, the JointVisual for the finished model is still visible.

content.raw: Tangentially related to this PR: Anyone know why joint type names differ between JointMaker and Joint? Could we use the same types (i.e. JointMaker uses types from Joint)? That way this block could simply be: `jointMsg->set_type(joint->type);`
content.html: Tangentially related to this PR: Anyone know why joint type names differ between JointMaker and Joint? Could we use the same types (i.e. JointMaker uses types from Joint)? That way this block could simply be: jointMsg->set_type(joint->type);

content.raw:
a viable alternative to lines 164-172 that would save lines:

```
_arrowVisual->ShowRotation(_type == msgs::Joint::REVOLUTE || _type == msgs::Joint::REVOLUTE2
       || _type == msgs::Joint::UNIVERSAL || _type == msgs::Joint::GEARBOX);
```
content.html:
a viable alternative to lines 164-172 that would save lines:

_arrowVisual->ShowRotation(_type == msgs::Joint::REVOLUTE || _type == msgs::Joint::REVOLUTE2
       || _type == msgs::Joint::UNIVERSAL || _type == msgs::Joint::GEARBOX);

content.raw:
I made some changes in 8efb534, `models_editor_joint_visuals_ian` branch, to minimize updates to the joint visual only when necessary mainly by using a few variables to track changes. You can consider mering it if it looks ok to you, thanks.

I also set a default axis value in joint inspector so that when a new joint gets added it has a non-zero axis
content.html:
I made some changes in 8efb534, models_editor_joint_visuals_ian branch, to minimize updates to the joint visual only when necessary mainly by using a few variables to track changes. You can consider mering it if it looks ok to you, thanks.

I also set a default axis value in joint inspector so that when a new joint gets added it has a non-zero axis
